historicalName: Calle San Giacomo in Sestiere di Santa Croce
englishName: Saint James Street in the District of Holy Cross
historicalDescription: This street was located in the sestiere of Santa Croce, known for its many churches and proximity to the Grand Canal. The nearby Church of San Giacomo dell'Orio, dating back to the 9th century, was a prominent landmark in the area during the 15th century.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the skilled artisans who crafted fine crystal glassware. Santa Croce had several workshops of specialized glassmakers who created high-quality crystal pieces for wealthy Venetian families and export.
Directly named after the nearby Calle San Giacomo, this dock would have served as the main water access point for the church of San Giacomo and surrounding neighborhood in Santa Croce.

Named after the Theatine Order who established the Church of San Nicolò da Tolentino in Santa Croce during the 16th century. This dock would have served the religious community and visitors to the church.

Santa Croce was home to numerous textile workshops, and this dock would have been used by weavers to receive raw materials and ship finished textiles, a crucial industry in Renaissance Venice's economy.

Referencing the name of the sestiere itself (Santa Croce - Holy Cross), this dock would have been an important landing point for the district, possibly near a prominent cross marker or a church dedicated to the Holy Cross.

The leather tanning industry was typically located in peripheral areas due to its odors. This area of Santa Croce, being somewhat removed from the city center, would have been suitable for leather processing workshops.
Unlike most of Venice, parts of Santa Croce had space for gardens and orchards. This dock might have been near notable gardens or served for transporting produce grown in the district's green spaces.

Stonemasons were vital to Venice's construction industry. This dock in Santa Croce would have been used for unloading stone materials brought in from the mainland and islands for building projects throughout the city.
Named after the Franciscan friars (Frati Minori) who had a presence in Santa Croce. This dock would have served their monastery and facilitated their charitable work in the community.

Butcher shops (beccarie) needed water access for waste disposal and receiving livestock. This dock in Santa Croce would have served the local meat contract, positioned away from more prestigious residential areas due to its nature.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the nearby Church of San Giacomo (Saint James) in Santa Croce sestiere. Many Venetian bridges were named after nearby churches or patron saints of the area, making this a historically accurate naming convention for a bridge in Calle San Giacomo.

The 'tiraoro' were Venetian artisans who specialized in creating gold leaf and gold thread, a prestigious craft in Renaissance Venice. This area of Santa Croce was known for various artisan workshops, and this bridge would commemorate the goldbeaters' guild that likely operated in the vicinity during the 15th-16th centuries.

This name references both the Sestiere di Santa Croce (Holy Cross) and a distinctive red cross that might have been displayed on a nearby building or shrine. During the Renaissance, religious symbols often marked important locations in Venice, and this bridge would commemorate such a landmark in the Santa Croce district.

Named after the noble Contarini family, one of Venice's most prominent nobili families who produced eight Doges between the 11th and 18th centuries. The Contarini likely owned property near Calle San Giacomo in Santa Croce, and it was common practice to name bridges after influential families who lived or owned palaces in the vicinity.

The 'filacanape' were craftsmen who made ropes, an essential trade for the maritime republic of Venice. Santa Croce's proximity to the Grand Canal and various boatyards (squeri) would have made it a logical location for ropemakers' workshops. This bridge would commemorate this vital maritime trade that would have been practiced near the waterways of Santa Croce in Renaissance Venice.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the silk weavers who operated workshops in this area during the 15th-16th centuries. The Venetian silk industry was prominent in Santa Croce, with many artisans living and working near San Giacomo.
Named after a small table or counter that was historically used by merchants to display their wares in this area. This spot near San Giacomo was known for small merchant stalls during contract days.

Once a canal that was filled in during the 16th century renovations. The name comes from the melon vendors who set up stalls along this route after the canal was converted to a street, supplying fresh produce to the Santa Croce district.

Named after a relief sculpture or sign of a dove that once adorned an archway in this covered passage. The dove symbolized the Holy Spirit and was connected to religious processions from the nearby Church of San Giacomo.

buildingPoints.streetName: Calle del Forno di San Giacomo
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the San Giacomo Bakery
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after one of the public ovens that operated here since medieval times. This bakery was especially important to the community surrounding San Giacomo, providing bread to local families.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Sausage Makers
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A paved street (salizada) named after the sausage makers who had their shops here. This food production area served the San Giacomo neighborhood, with the guild of luganegheri being particularly active in Santa Croce during the 16th century.

A commercial street named after the lace makers who sold their delicate handmade products here. This craft was particularly associated with female artisans working in the Santa Croce district, near the San Giacomo area.

Named after the earthenware pot makers or sellers who had workshops around this small square. Their products were essential for Venetian kitchens, and this manufacturing activity was concentrated near San Giacomo in the 15th century.

Named after a wool or silk spinning workshop that operated here during the Renaissance period. Textile production was a major industry in Santa Croce, with various stages of production taking place in buildings along this street.

Named after the noble Bragadin family who owned property along this canal-side street. This nobili family had significant influence in the San Giacomo area of Santa Croce during the 15th and 16th centuries.

A former canal filled in during urban renovations, named after the shoemakers who established their workshops along this street. The guild of shoemakers had a strong presence in Santa Croce, particularly around San Giacomo.
A small courtyard named after the Ballarin family, who were merchants and owned property in this area of Santa Croce. Their residence faced this courtyard near San Giacomo during the 16th century.

Named after glassmakers who had small workshops in this area before most glass production was consolidated on Murano. Some finishing work and glass bead production continued here in Santa Croce near San Giacomo throughout the Renaissance.

A covered passageway named after the candlemakers who worked in this area. Their craft was essential for lighting homes and churches in the San Giacomo neighborhood, and many operated from small workshops along this covered passage.

A small side street named after a hole or opening in a wall that once existed here, possibly referring to a drainage point or architectural feature. This peculiar landmark became a reference point for locals in the San Giacomo area.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of Our Lady of Carmel
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a shrine or image of the Madonna that was particularly venerated by residents of this street near San Giacomo. The Carmelite devotion was popular in Renaissance Venice, especially in the Santa Croce district.

A canal-side street named after the helmsmen who lived in this area. Many ship navigators made their homes in Santa Croce near San Giacomo due to its proximity to the maritime activities of the western side of Venice.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Pitch Workers
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A paved street named after workers who processed pitch used for waterproofing boats. This naval-related craft was concentrated in Santa Croce, with many workshops near San Giacomo serving the nearby boatyards.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Guardians of the School
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the guardians or caretakers of a scuola (confraternity building) that once stood near San Giacomo. These lay religious brotherhoods were important civic institutions in Renaissance Venice, particularly in the Santa Croce district.

A courtyard named after a small arsenal or storage facility for weapons that existed here in the 15th-16th centuries. Its location in Santa Croce near San Giacomo made it strategically important for the defense of this part of the city.

buildingPoints.streetName: Rio Terà dei Tintori di Lana
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of the Wool Dyers
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A former canal filled in during the 16th century, named after the wool dyers who established workshops along this street. The textile industry was particularly strong in Santa Croce, with specialized dye houses operating near San Giacomo.

buildingPoints.streetName: Calle della Fraterna di San Giacomo
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Brotherhood of San Giacomo
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a lay religious brotherhood associated with the Church of San Giacomo. This confraternity provided charitable services to the community and organized religious processions throughout the Santa Croce district.

A covered passage that led toward or passed under the bell tower of the Church of San Giacomo. This architectural feature was an important landmark and reference point for navigation through the narrow streets of Santa Croce.

A canal-side street named after the coppersmiths who had workshops along this waterway. Metal crafting was an important industry in Santa Croce, with these artisans producing cookware and decorative items near San Giacomo.

Named after small private chapels or prayer rooms that existed along this street. Several nobili families in the San Giacomo area maintained these oratories for private worship during the Renaissance period.

A commercial street named after the cobblers or shoemakers who set up shops along this row. The leather craft was particularly important in the Santa Croce district, with many workshops concentrated near San Giacomo.

Named after reported miraculous events or a miraculous image that was venerated in this small square. Local religious devotion was strong in the San Giacomo area, with this site becoming a place of popular piety during the Renaissance.

Named after a former convent that existed here before the Renaissance restructuring of the city. Although the religious house was repurposed or demolished, its memory was preserved in the street name near San Giacomo.

Once a canal that was filled in during urban renovations, named after the shoemakers who established their workshops along this route. The concentration of leather workers in this area of Santa Croce near San Giacomo was significant during the 15th-16th centuries.

A covered passage leading to or past a fontego (warehouse) where goods were stored after arriving by boat. This commercial infrastructure was important to the trading activities in the San Giacomo area of Santa Croce.

buildingPoints.streetName: Calle del Traghetto di Santa Croce
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Santa Croce Ferry
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a gondola ferry crossing point that connected this part of Santa Croce to other districts across the Grand Canal. The traghetto was an essential transportation link for residents of the San Giacomo neighborhood during the Renaissance.
